column3: Historically, we've always used a Local Group Policy and then Intune Configuration Profile called "Prohibit access to Control Panel and PC settings (User)" which would block standard users from being able to launch the Control Panel or PC Settings menu. Generally, standard users don't have any reason to access Control Panel, but PC Settings causes some workflow issues and the requirement of someone from the Enterprise Service Desk to connect to the system and help configure items like Display or Sound settings from an administrator account. With Intune, we now have the ability to set a configuration profile to allow only specific sub menus in the PC Settings Menu, while hiding everything else. Control Panel won't technically be "prohibited" once we make this change, but standard users are unable to search within the Start Menu, use the Run dialogue, or run the Control Panel via other means, so it's essentially out of sight, out of mind. With this change implemented, standard users will be able to launch the Settings Manu and it will display sub-menus for Display and Sound settings, so standard users can configure their own monitor topologies, connect their own headsets and change output/input settings. This will reduce the time required to make these basic changes, since someone with administrator access won't be required. Even if someone from the Enterprise Service Desk is required to help make the change, being able to access these basic settings from the standard user account, it cuts down on the number of steps and amount of time required to make the change initially and troubleshooting later on.
column14: Allow Display and Sound Settings on PCI Machines via Intune
column24: While this isn't mission critical, not implementing this continues to keep setup and troubleshooting for basic settings higher and can cause issues with people in meetings if they are unable to access their sound settings for example and need someone in IT to use an administrator account to fix sound input/output.
column25: Control Panel and Settings Menu won't be prohibited. Settings Menu will be controlled via the new configuration profile that will only display the sub-menus we allow. In this case Display and Sound settings. Control Panel isn't accessible from a standard user account because standard users cannot search for it, use the Run dialogue, and it won't be available in the Start Menu.Acceptance Criteria is to apply the new settings, remove the old settings, and allow end users to manage display and sound settings.Without implementing this change, administrator access is required for basic system settings like Display and Sound settings. This increases initial setup time as well as troubleshooting time later on.

This works as expected and opens up Display and Sound settings and doesn't make menus like Control Panel or other Settings Menu options available.
